Ristresso Series. UKBC

18/05/2012

Last weekend's UK Barista Championships has taught us some tricks for making interesting cups of coffee. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Robert Sharp)

Image by

By James Bithell

Last weekend (28th April) saw the Finals of the UK Barista Championship at the London Coffee Festival; twenty baristas battled it out over two days to be crowned champion. First place and best cappuccino went to Maxwell Colonna-Dashwood (of Colonna & Smalls, Bath), second and best espresso and signature drink to James Bailey (of Prufrock Coffee, London) and third to Howard Barwick (of Opposite, Victoria Quarter, Leeds). Each competitor had to make 4 espressos, 4 cappuccinos and 4 signature drinks in 15 minutes. While the technical demands of shot times and spillages may not matter to us everyday coffee imbibers, the signature drinks might give us a little inspiration to mess about with a cup of java.
This week's post will round up some of the tools, themes and tricks that were thrown up from the signature drinks and maybe give you some ideas to mess about with... Infusion One of the most basic ways of introducing other flavours into the signature drinks was infusing other liquids with flavours that interacted with an espresso shot. Rummy Keshett used milk infusion to create a popcorn element which matched the flavour profile of the coffee, and added a caramel syrup to match the flavour of coffee in milk, accentuating the coffee elements by matching them. Infusing milk like this is pretty easy, bring to the just off the boil with whatever you want to infuse in the liquid, cool and leave for 10-20 minutes (depending on the strength of the flavour). Howard Barwick used a syphon (posh chemistry set, basically brewer atop a bowl-bottle over a Bunsen burner) to extract flavours into water which balanced against his coffee, using sultana, cranberry and cascara (the casing of the bean). Adding this to iced espresso and soda water with a dash of lemon and lime juice. Fruit infusion + acidic soda + iced espresso = a real cool summer pick-me-up. Mark Lamberton used an aeropress to infuse water with avocado, strawberry, palm sugar and salt; the strawberry again matched the profile of the coffee, with the avocado oils giving a body and smooth 'mouthfeel'. Neither the aeropress or siphon are strictly necessary for water infusion, give it a go in a pan or teapot! Taste elements Human taste has 5 basic elements, with flavours other from this being imparted by aroma: sweet, salt, bitter, sour (and umami - think savoury and yummy; parmesan, ripe tomatoes, soy, fish). Many of the baristas played with or covered most of the 4 better-known elements. Maxwell Colonna-Dashwood used strong flavours to occlude the taste elements in the coffee, bringing out the other tastes in his espresso. Grapefruit juice would drown out the acidity of the coffee, bringing out rich, sweet bitterness, while spicy liquorice and star anise infusion brought back the tart flavours. Try this with any strong acidic or bitter flavour while tasting coffee. James Bailey deconstructed the four main elements, using different ingredients of the drink to reflect each - with lactose [sweet], malic acid (think green apple) and tartaric acid (grape acid)[sour], salt [salty] and espresso [bitterness]. Howard Barwick focussed on balancing just the sweet and bitter with a fruit infusion to match the bitter coffee. Origin Another cool theme that emerged was based on manipulating origin. Alex Sargent used ingredients in his sig drink that matched the origin of the coffee he was using (Guatemalan); cardamom is the biggest export from Guatemala, so he used a simple cardamom syrup to accentuate the profile of the bean, along with some chocolate etching and a flamed orange peel for essential oils (an old cocktail trick). Steve Dyson, of Spring Espresso York (Fossgate), took the origin idea into a different direction, basing his sig drink on a legendary York flavour combination - the chocolate orange. Achieved with 2ml of reduced orange, an injection of molten chocolate mixed with an espresso shot - topped off by, well, a special finale (see next section). Cool Tools Apart from the amazing glassware on show, many of the baristas used some cool food-tech to create their signature drinks. Alongside the coffee techs that have been already mentioned, dry ice, liquid nitrogen canisters, syringes were all used to wow the judging panels. Nitro canisters were used to hold and serve various concoctions, including a chocolate espuma (light airy mousse) to mix with espresso. Gordon Howell from The Attic at Harlequins (York) brewed his own non-alcoholic porter using some light and dark malts (think craft stout, chocolatey) brewed and mixed with some hops and wort, then used the nitro canister to serve the mixture, so it poured like a stout. The flavours in the porter complemented the (potion bottle) decanted espresso and also represented what they do at The Attic, serve speciality coffee and craft beer. Steve Dyson, of Spring Espresso, used essential orange oils in water, poured over a display of oranges over dry ice, to create a stylish orange smoke/mist finale to his sig drink. Now, most of these techniques or equipment aren't really available to us (unless you're a chemistry student), but the ideas can be scaled down. Why not try some of them in your next coffee?
